title: Pushing the Performance of Synthetic Speech Detection with Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks and Self-Supervised Learning Models
author: Tuan Dat Phuong (Hanoi University of Science and Technology), Long-Vu Hoang (Hanoi University of Science and Technology), Huy Dat Tran (Institute for Infocomm Research, A*STAR), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces a new architecture that utilizes Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks, which could enhance function approximation capabilities in various audio-related tasks, thus potentially benefiting Haohe Liu's research on audio generation and restoration.
background: Detecting synthetic speech to differentiate between genuine and spoofed audio in a biometric authentication framework.
contribution: This paper introduces Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks to replace traditional Multi-Layer Perceptrons for improved detection of synthetic speech, achieving up to a 67.1% relative reduction in error rates.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous synthetic speech detection methods typically relied on Multi-Layer Perceptrons, which struggle with high-dimensional data due to their fixed activation functions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon existing methods by employing Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks that utilize learnable activation functions, which better capture complex mappings in speech data.

key_innovation: The unique approach of using learnable activation functions in Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks allows for a more flexible and efficient model for approximating complex functions involved in synthetic speech detection.
real_world_impact: This advancement has the potential to significantly improve the accuracy of biometric speech verification systems, thereby enhancing security against spoofing attacks in practical applications.
limitations: The authors did not explicitly mention any limitations in their study.

new_terms.Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks: **Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs)** are a class of neural networks inspired by a mathematical theorem that allows complex functions to be approximated as sums of simpler univariate functions.
